Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's decisions to deny cancellation of interest and penalties on late-filed tax returns were reasonable
Evidence_Assessment: Personal challenges (deaths in family, illness), reliance on third parties for filing
Legal_Rule: The Minister may waive or cancel penalties and interest under s. 220(3.1) if justified by extraordinary circumstances beyond the taxpayer's control
Grounds_for_Claim: Extraordinary circumstances due to personal hardships and third-party errors
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Family deaths, illness, reliance on third parties for tax filing
Applicant_Challenge: Challenge to denial of penalty and interest relief
Legal_Rule_Source: Income Tax Act, s. 220(3.1); relevant case law
Defendant_Response: Minister considered factors but denied relief based on taxpayer responsibility for third-party actions
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal circumstances, third-party involvement
Legal_Provision: s. 220(3.1) of the Income Tax Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 220(3.1) of the Income Tax Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to file on time due to personal circumstances and third-party errors
Applicable_Process: Application for waiver under s. 220(3.1); judicial review
Governing_Rule: Taxpayers are responsible for fulfilling their tax obligations regardless of third-party involvement
